Impression: N2 positive (Stn 7).

note_text:
HISTORY: Mr. Martinez presented for mediastinal staging of a right upper lobe non-small cell lung cancer. 
PROCEDURE: Endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial needle aspiration was systematically performed under moderate sedation. The lymph node stations were interrogated in the standard sequence. Station 7 (subcarinal) demonstrated immediate positivity for malignancy on rapid on-site evaluation. Station 4R (right paratracheal), despite PET avidity, required multiple passes to achieve adequate cellularity and appeared benign. Station 11R was also sampled. 
CONCLUSION: Confirmed N2 disease involving the subcarinal station.

note_text: The patient arrived for staging of his right upper lobe cancer. We used moderate sedation and inserted the EBUS scope. We started by sampling station 4R, which was difficult to get a good sample from but eventually showed benign cells. We then moved to the subcarinal node (station 7), which was clearly malignant on the first few passes. Finally, we sampled the hilar node (11R). The procedure confirmed cancer spread to the mediastinum.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA
Patient: Henry Walker, 63-year-old male with a spiculated right upper lobe mass and borderline mediastinal nodes.
Indication: Mediastinal staging prior to lobectomy.
Setting: Bronchoscopy suite, Harbor Pulmonary Institute. Deep sedation with propofol infusion, native airway with bite block and supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.
Findings: Normal vocal cords. Central airways patent without visible endobronchial tumor. Mild extrinsic compression at right mainstem.
EBUS: Olympus BF-UC180F scope used. Systematic survey of mediastinum. Lymph nodes identified and sampled at 2R, 4R, and 7 using 21G Vizishot needle. Three passes obtained per station. ROSE adequate at all stations with lymphocytes only; no definite malignant cells.
No elastography or intranodal forceps biopsies performed.
Complications: None. EBL <5 mL. No hypoxia or arrhythmia.
Disposition: Observed in recovery for 90 minutes and discharged home with standard postbronchoscopy instructions.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Mediastinal staging for right upper lobe lung mass
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 3.0 cm spiculated RUL mass with borderline 2R, 4R nodes on CT
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Adequate lymphocytes at all stations; no definite malignant cells on ROSE
registry_entry.ebus_stations_detail: Three passes per station, samples sent for cytology and cell block.
registry_entry.bronch_indication: EBUS-TBNA for mediastinal staging
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Cytology and cell block with immunohistochemistry if malignant cells found
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: No mediastinal metastasis identified on ROSE; final cytology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Thoracic surgery clinic within 1 week to review final results and plan resection

coding_review.rationale: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA under deep sedation sampled nodal stations 2R, 4R, and 7 for staging of a right upper lobe mass. Because three stations were sampled in one staging session, 31653 is the appropriate single EBUS code.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Flexible Bronchoscopy with Linear EBUS-TBNA.
CLINICAL SUMMARY: 63-year-old male with RUL mass and borderline adenopathy.
OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: The patient was placed under deep sedation. A systematic mediastinal survey was conducted using the Olympus BF-UC180F. Lymph node stations 2R, 4R, and 7 were visualized and sampled using a 21-gauge aspiration needle. Rapid on-site evaluation demonstrated adequate lymphoid tissue without evidence of metastasis at all sampled stations.
IMPRESSION: Negative mediastinal staging by EBUS (N0 by EBUS).

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Linear EBUS-TBNA under general anesthesia in the operating room
Patient: Allison Parker, 57-year-old female with biopsy-proven right lower lobe adenocarcinoma and equivocal PET uptake in subcarinal node.
Indication: Mediastinal staging (station 7) prior to definitive therapy.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 7.5 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
EBUS Details: Fujifilm EB-530US scope advanced through ETT. Stations 4R, 7, and 10R evaluated. A 22G needle was used; four passes obtained from station 7, three from 4R, two from 10R. ROSE demonstrated malignant cells at station 7 consistent with adenocarcinoma; other stations reactive.
No elastography available; no intranodal forceps performed.
Complications: None. EBL ~5 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to PACU in stable condition; admitted to oncology floor.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Mediastinal staging for right lower lobe adenocarcinoma
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Right lower lobe mass with borderline subcarinal node, mild PET uptake at station 7
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Station 7 positive for malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma; 4R and 10R reactive
registry_entry.ebus_stations_detail: Multiple passes at each station with adequate lymphoid tissue on ROSE.
registry_entry.bronch_indication: EBUS-TBNA for mediastinal staging
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Cytology, cell block, immunohistochemistry
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: N2 disease at station 7; final cytology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Tumor board review; likely definitively treated with chemoradiation rather than surgery

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Linear Endobronchial Ultrasound.
INDICATION: 57F with biopsy-proven RLL adenocarcinoma.
NARRATIVE: Under general anesthesia, the mediastinum was staged. Stations 4R, 7, and 10R were identified. Transbronchial needle aspiration confirmed metastatic adenocarcinoma in the subcarinal station (7), confirming N2 disease. The paratracheal and hilar stations appeared reactive on preliminary assessment.
IMPRESSION: Stage IIIA (N2) Adenocarcinoma.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Linear EBUS with Elastography and Intranodal Forceps Biopsy.
INDICATION: Evaluation of mediastinal adenopathy, rule out sarcoidosis.
NARRATIVE: EBUS visualization revealed enlarged nodes at stations 4R, 7, and 11L. Elastography patterns were recorded. TBNA was performed at all stations. To increase diagnostic yield for granulomatous disease, intranodal forceps biopsies were obtained from station 7. ROSE confirmed granulomatous inflammation consistent with sarcoidosis.
IMPRESSION: Pulmonary Sarcoidosis.

note_text: Mr. Johnson underwent an EBUS procedure to investigate swollen lymph nodes in his chest. We suspected sarcoidosis. We sampled three different node stations using a needle. To be sure we got enough tissue to diagnose sarcoidosis, we also used tiny forceps to take a small bite of tissue from the largest node (station 7). The preliminary look in the microscope showed the typical inflammation seen in sarcoidosis.

registry_entry.note_text:
Bronchoscopy Procedure Note
Procedure: Radial EBUS-guided biopsy of right middle lobe nodule (no navigation)
Patient: Janice Moore, 71-year-old female with 15 mm RML nodule not amenable to CT-guided biopsy.
Sedation: Moderate sedation (midazolam and fentanyl), native airway.
Procedure summary:
- Diagnostic bronchoscopy performed; central airways normal.
- Radial EBUS catheter advanced through guide sheath into RML lateral segment based on fluoroscopy and CT roadmap.
- Concentric solid lesion pattern obtained.
- Four transbronchial forceps biopsies and two brushings performed through guide sheath.
ROSE: Suspicious for malignancy.
Complications: Minimal bleeding. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home after observation.

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 15 mm solid RML lateral segment nodule abutting bronchus; no adenopathy
registry_entry.lesion_location: Right middle lobe lateral segment peripheral nodule
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Atypical cells suspicious for non-small cell carcinoma
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS view within lesion
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopic confirmation of guide sheath position
registry_entry.nav_sampling_tools: Transbronchial forceps and cytology brush via guide sheath
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Radial EBUS-guided biopsy of RML nodule
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, immunohistochemistry, molecular panel if NSCLC confirmed
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspicious for NSCLC; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Lung nodule clinic appointment in 710 days to review results

cpt_modifications: Removed 31627 (computer-assisted navigation add-on) because the note documents radial EBUS with fluoroscopic guidance and explicitly states that no navigation system was used.
registry_fixes: Set registry_entry.nav_platform to null to reflect that no computer-assisted navigation system was used for this radial EBUS-guided biopsy.

registry_entry.note_text:
Robotic Bronchoscopy / EBUS Note
Procedures:
1. Ion robotic-assisted bronchoscopy
2. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT
3. Transbronchial cryobiopsy and forceps biopsy of LUL nodule
Patient: Olivia Carter, 59-year-old female with 20 mm left upper lobe nodule and normal mediastinal imaging.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT; pressure control ventilation.
Details: Robotic catheter navigated to apicoposterior segment of LUL using CT-to-body registration (error 2.1 mm). Concentric radial EBUS view obtained. Cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion. Three cryobiopsies (1.1 mm cryoprobe) and three standard forceps biopsies performed.
ROSE from cryobiopsy: Malignant epithelial cells, favor adenocarcinoma.
Complications: Mild bleeding, controlled with wedging. No pneumothorax on immediate cone-beam CT.
Disposition: Extubated and discharged from PACU after uneventful recovery.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Biopsy of solitary LUL pulmonary nodule
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 20 mm irregular LUL apicoposterior segment nodule; no adenopathy
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Malignant epithelial cells consistent with adenocarcinoma on cryobiopsy
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Concentric radial EBUS pattern within lesion
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Cone-beam CT pre- and post-biopsy
registry_entry.nav_sampling_tools: Cryoprobe 1.1 mm and transbronchial forceps
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy for LUL nodule
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Robotic navigation, radial EBUS, cone-beam CT
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Histology, immunohistochemistry, molecular profiling, PD-L1
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Non-small cell lung carcinoma, favor adenocarcinoma on ROSE
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Lung cancer clinic visit in 1 week for staging and treatment planning

coding_review.rationale: Ion robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS guidance was performed for a peripheral left upper lobe nodule, with both transbronchial forceps biopsies and transbronchial cryobiopsies under general anesthesia. 31628 captures the transbronchial lung biopsies, 31645 reflects the additional therapeutic aspiration or cryobiopsy work per local mapping, and add-on 31627 is supported by the documented CT-to-body registration and robotic navigation steps.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Robotic-Assisted Bronchoscopy with Cone-Beam CT and Cryobiopsy.
INDICATION: Solitary LUL pulmonary nodule.
NARRATIVE: The Ion robotic catheter was registered and navigated to the target in the apicoposterior segment of the LUL. Localization was multimodal: radial EBUS (concentric) and Cone-Beam CT (tool-in-lesion). Transbronchial cryobiopsies and standard forceps biopsies were obtained. ROSE confirmed adenocarcinoma. 
IMPRESSION: Primary Lung Adenocarcinoma.

Disposition: Extubated and discharged from PACU after uneventful recovery.

Patient: Olivia Carter

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy (superDimension) with radial EBUS and transbronchial biopsies of left lower lobe nodule.
Patient: Daniel Rivera, 65-year-old male with 14 mm LLL peripheral nodule with faint PET uptake.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Highlights:
- EMN plan created from thin-cut CT; registration error 4.6 mm via anatomical landmarks.
- Radial EBUS showed eccentric view.
- Fluoroscopy confirmed position at lesion; no cone-beam CT available.
- Five forceps biopsies, two brushings and one mini-BAL obtained.
ROSE: Nondiagnostic, bronchial cells only.
Complications: None. No pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR.
Disposition: Discharged home with plan for repeat evaluation vs CT-guided biopsy.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Biopsy of small indeterminate LLL pulmonary nodule
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 14 mm LLL lateral basal nodule with faint PET uptake; no adenopathy
registry_entry.lesion_location: Left lower lobe lateral basal segment
registry_entry.anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, topical and nebulized lidocaine
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Bronchial epithelial cells only, nondiagnostic
registry_entry.nav_rebus_view: Eccentric radial EBUS view
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy only
registry_entry.nav_sampling_tools: Transbronchial forceps, cytology brush, mini-BAL catheter
registry_entry.bronch_indication: ENB-guided biopsy of LLL nodule
registry_entry.bronch_tbbx_tool: Standard transbronchial forceps via extended working channel
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Histology and cytology
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Nondiagnostic bronchoscopic biopsy; additional tissue sampling likely needed
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Lung nodule clinic in 2 weeks to review options

coding_review.rationale: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS was used to reach a left lower lobe nodule under moderate sedation, followed by multiple transbronchial lung biopsies. 31628 is supported by the documented biopsies and 31627 is supported by the detailed EMN planning and navigation, with no additional EBUS or therapeutic airway codes indicated.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Electromagnetic Navigational Bronchoscopy.
INDICATION: Indeterminate LLL nodule.
NARRATIVE: Using the superDimension system, a pathway was mapped to the LLL lateral basal segment. The locatable guide was advanced to the target. Radial EBUS revealed an eccentric view, suggesting the probe was adjacent to the lesion. Fluoroscopy confirmed position. Biopsies and brushings were obtained but ROSE was nondiagnostic.
IMPRESSION: Nondiagnostic bronchoscopy.

note_text:
Indication: Tracheal stenosis (post-intubation).
Proc: Rigid bronch, Balloon dilation, Silicone Stent.
Details: 70% subglottic stenosis. Dilated to 12mm. 12x40mm Dumon stent placed. Residual 10% narrowing.
Plan: Admit overnight.

registry_entry.note_text:
Central Airway Therapeutic Bronchoscopy Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis
3. Silicone stent placement
Patient: Patrick Hughes, 58-year-old male with prior prolonged intubation now with fixed upper airway obstruction and exertional stridor.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope size 11 and jet ventilation.
Findings: Short-segment concentric fibrotic stenosis 2 cm below vocal cords; ~70% luminal narrowing.
Intervention: Serial balloon dilations performed to 12 mm, then a 12 x 40 mm silicone straight stent placed across the stenotic segment. Postprocedure lumen patency ~10% residual narrowing.
Complications: Minor mucosal bleeding controlled with epinephrine.
Disposition: Extubated to PACU on 4 L nasal cannula and admitted overnight for airway monitoring.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Symptomatic postintubation tracheal stenosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT neck/chest showing 1.5 cm segment of subglottic tracheal narrowing ~6 mm diameter
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Brief trial of inhaled steroids and dilation at outside hospital
registry_entry.nav_imaging_verification: Fluoroscopy for balloon sizing and stent position
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for tracheal stenosis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Rigid bronchoscopy with fluoroscopy for stent positioning
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Benign postintubation tracheal stenosis treated with balloon dilation and silicone stent
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Clinic bronchoscopy in 46 weeks to reassess stent position and lumen

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
cpt_summary.rationale: Placement of silicone tracheal stent; includes dilation.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy with tracheal stent placement

coding_review.rationale: Rigid bronchoscopy under general anesthesia treated severe benign distal tracheal stenosis with balloon dilation and placement of a silicone tracheal stent. 31631 appropriately reflects the tracheal stent placement, and a separate dilation code is not added because dilation is inherent to stent deployment.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Therapeutic Rigid Bronchoscopy for Tracheal Stenosis.
INDICATION: Exertional stridor, benign tracheal stenosis.
NARRATIVE: Rigid bronchoscopy identified a concentric fibrotic stenosis in the subglottic trachea. The lesion was dilated serially with balloons. A 12x40mm silicone stent was deployed to maintain patency. The airway caliber significantly improved.
IMPRESSION: Successful recanalization and stenting of benign tracheal stenosis.

registry_entry.note_text:
Central Airway Therapeutic Bronchoscopy Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis
3. Silicone stent placement
Patient: Patrick Hughes, 58-year-old male with prior prolonged intubation now with fixed upper airway obstruction and exertional stridor.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope size 11 and jet ventilation.
Findings: Short-segment concentric fibrotic stenosis 2 cm below vocal cords; ~70% luminal narrowing.
Intervention: Serial balloon dilations performed to 12 mm, then a 12 x 40 mm silicone straight stent placed across the stenotic segment. Postprocedure lumen patency ~10% residual narrowing.
Complications: Minor mucosal bleeding controlled with epinephrine.
Disposition: Extubated to PACU on 4 L nasal cannula and admitted overnight for airway monitoring.

registry_entry.note_text:
Rigid Bronchoscopy Procedure Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy and mechanical debulking
2. Balloon dilation of left mainstem bronchus
Patient: Brenda Lewis, 73-year-old female with benign left mainstem bronchial stenosis after lung transplant.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid size 12 bronchoscope, jet ventilation.
Findings: Fibrotic annular stenosis at anastomotic site in left mainstem with ~60% narrowing and retained secretions distally.
Interventions: Mechanical dilation with rigid barrel and forceps followed by controlled balloon dilation to 10 mm. No stent placed.
Complications: Small mucosal tear without active bleeding. EBL ~20 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in OR, transferred to PACU then transplant ward.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Benign anastomotic stenosis after lung transplant
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest showing focal narrowing of left mainstem bronchus at anastomosis with distal air trapping
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Bronchoscopic balloon dilation x1 approximately 6 months prior
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic bronchoscopic dilation of transplant anastomosis
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Small mucosal tear without ongoing bleeding
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Benign post-transplant anastomotic stenosis with improved lumen post dilation
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 3 months or sooner if symptoms recur

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Rigid Bronchoscopy with Balloon Dilation.
INDICATION: Benign anastomotic stenosis post-lung transplant.
NARRATIVE: The left mainstem anastomosis was inspected via rigid bronchoscopy and found to be stenotic (60% narrowing). Mechanical dilation was performed using the rigid barrel, followed by balloon dilation to 10mm. Stenting was deferred. A small mucosal tear was noted but hemostasis was achieved.
IMPRESSION: Improved anastomotic patency.

Complications: Small mucosal tear without active bleeding. EBL ~20 mL.
Disposition: Extubated in OR, transferred to PACU then transplant ward.

registry_entry.note_text:
Central Airway Stenting Note
Procedures:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking
2. Y-shaped silicone stent placement
Patient: Raymond Scott, 69-year-old male with squamous cell carcinoma of the carina causing severe central airway obstruction.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope and intermittent jet ventilation.
Findings: Bulky endobronchial tumor involving distal trachea and extending into both mainstem bronchi causing ~80% obstruction.
Interventions: Mechanical debulking with rigid barrel and forceps followed by argon plasma coagulation. A custom 14 x 60/40 mm silicone Y stent was deployed with the main limb in distal trachea and branches in right and left main bronchi.
Complications: Brief desaturation during stent deployment, resolved with recruitment.
Disposition: Remained intubated postprocedure and transferred to ICU.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Rigid Bronchoscopy, Tumor Debulking, and Y-Stent Placement.
INDICATION: Malignant central airway obstruction.
NARRATIVE: Large squamous cell carcinoma involving the carina was visualized. Significant debulking was achieved using mechanical coring and APC. To maintain patency of the distal trachea and both mainstems, a silicone Y-stent was deployed. Patient required recruitment post-deployment due to desaturation.
IMPRESSION: Palliation of critical carinal obstruction.

note_text: Mr. Scott had a large tumor blocking the split of his windpipe (carina). We performed an emergency procedure to open the airway. Using a rigid scope, we scraped away the tumor and burned the base. Then, we placed a Y-shaped silicone stent that holds open the trachea and both lung tubes. He had a brief drop in oxygen levels during the stent placement but recovered. He stays on the ventilator in the ICU for now.

Bronchoscopy with bronchial stent placement, initial bronchus
Bronchoscopy with tracheal stent placement

coding_review.rationale: Therapeutic bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction used rigid coring and argon plasma coagulation tumor debulking of the right mainstem bronchus followed by deployment of a Y silicone stent spanning the distal trachea and mainstem bronchi. 31641 captures the endobronchial tumor destruction or relief of stenosis, while 31631 and 31636 capture the tracheal and mainstem bronchial stent placement components respectively; no separate dilation code is added because stent placement codes include necessary dilation.
